title: How to write my name in Chinese - Quora

response.answer_text: Ja Su Lin might be a nice way to break up your name for Asian languages. (Korean: Ja Sul Lin ; Japanese: Ja Su Rin.) 嘉 素林 嘉 Ja (good) 素 Su (White or light coloured) 林 Lin (forest) I think this is a nice name that matches you phonetically, is not too odd or grandiose a name and has good meanings and strokes. If you find the overpronounsiation of the S in Jasleen maybe just Ja Lin would be fine too: 嘉林 Also, I’m assuming Jasleen is the female name which means “Good reputation” so matching the meaning to Ja 嘉 is always a bonus in my eyes. A lot of comments below say 思 (Su) meaning think is a good character if 素 is too plain for you. You can also pick out any characters which are meaningful to you that match up phonetically.

hi！I am a Chinese student majoring in English. Maybe I can answer this question. According to the pronunciation, your name is commonly known as 奈嘉/奈格儿in Chinese.But I think your name is best translated as 【奈嘉】or【奈佳】My reasons are as follows： 1.【奈】（nài） If you have some knowledge of Chinese history, you may know that some modern Chinese characters correspond to ancient Chinese characters. For example，The word 【奈】 corresponds to the ancient word 【耐】，This word can be understood as "patience”and “endurance".It can also be interpreted as "a strong willpower and a strong personality".In Chinese culture, our nation has always praised this character.This is also the character that every Chinese hopes future generations will have.Morever，The family name“奈" is rare in China.If you come to China to study or communicate, this can help you avoid some embarrassment of name repetition.Some names based on translation software or Internet trends will always appear common or strange, for example, many Chinese people's English names are jack or rose. Then，let's talk about how to choose your first name.I think 【嘉】or 【佳】is very good as your first name.And I will analyze their meanings in detail below, which can help you make better decisions 2.【嘉】（jiā） This is a very complicated Chinese character in the eyes of foreigners.But despite its complexity, it is one of the most popular names in China. The original meaning of this word is“击鼓吹笙，庆贺奖赏”，You can think of it as "something that deserves a lot of pleasure and praise."And many ancient poems and books have explained the word： 嘉，美也。——东汉·许慎《说文解字》（“嘉”stands for "beautiful" and "praiseworthy."—《Origin of Chinese Characters》）嘉，善也。——《尔雅》（“嘉”stands for "goodness"—《Er Ya》）………..The word "嘉”is a symbol of good things and also a symbol of the Chinese people's expectation for the future life. If you choose "嘉", it means that you are initially integrated into Chinese culture 3.【佳】（jiā） The word "佳" combines all good meanings. Firstly，The word "佳" stands for a person's beautiful appearance. （姱修滂浩， 丽以佳只—《楚辞·大招》）（A slender, well-built woman is the most beautiful—《Songs of the South 》 Secondly，（鹿门有佳士，博览无不识。—《寄周安孺茶》（“佳士”represents a man of great learning） Besides，"佳" represents for good human character in China.（兰有秀兮菊有芳，怀佳人兮不能忘—《秋风辞》）（“佳人”represents a man of talent and good character） From what has been discussed above，I think "奈嘉" or "奈佳" is the most suitable Chinese names for you.If you don't like these two names, you can reply to me and I will give you other Suggestions.Thanks！

珥琳 (Ěr-lín) or 愛爾琳 (Ài-ěr-lín) There are many characters in Chinese that have the same pronunciation. You can play around with the different characters that have the same pronunciation, find one you like, and stick with it. The more advanced way is you can play around with the tones. Using the different tones in Chinese, you can combine them to form the one that sounds just like your name or something similar enough to your name but sounds prettier. Once you’ve done that, then you can go back to choosing the right characters for those tones. With the two names I’ve provided, the former one is the one that sounds most like your name but the latter sounds prettier. As I’ve mentioned before, there are many characters that are pronounced “er” so you can make it 愛珥琳 as well, or any other combination that you see fit. Hope this helps!

You mean you don’t have a Chinese name and wish to create one. If that’s the case you will have total freedom in choosing any Chinese name you like. Chinese name usually has meaning and choosing a name is not a random process. Sometimes you may have chosen a name with some profound meaning but the sound rhyme with something stupid or not nice, that’s the worst outcome. It happens from time to time and not being a Chinese, you won’t know until someone tells you with a grimace or an outright laugh. So it’s better to let a knowledgeable Chinese (not me) do that for you. What I can do is to give you some basic guidelines. In general you want a name which sounds similar to your English name. On this route, there are two ways to go. The first is simple transliteration. That would work best for common names like David or John. The second method is to choose a name with good meaning but also has similar sound. This is more difficult and is an art rather than science. This is better done by Chinese with good background in Chinese language or literature. If you ask me, your last name can be 古 (meaning ancient) or 谷 (meaning valley), the former is a common Chinese last name, and the latter is less common but still a lot of Chinese have that last name. There are many possibilities for your first name depending on whether you are a he or she. If you are a he, it may be 新瑞 (meaning new luck). If you are a she, it may be 心立 (meaning a resolute heart). My suggestion only. Note for Chinese, the last name go first so it will be 古新瑞 or 古心立. Actually on second thought, both names are quite gender neutral and can be used for either sex.

By typical Chinese naming conventions, your name is 瓦伦= Wa+lun. Words in ‘V’ is always translated into a character with a ‘w’ sound, becos there's no ‘v’ sound in Mandarin. Hence ‘Va’ becomes ‘Wa’. 瓦 is the common character to translate ‘Wa’ in Mandarin, as can be seen in ‘Wa’ in ‘Walter’: 瓦尔特 walter - Google Search ‘r’ sound is typically translated into Mandarin ‘L’ sound. Hence, ‘roon’ becomes ‘lun(aka ‘loon’)’. 伦 is the typical character to write ‘lun’ in, as can be seen in: 瓦伦·达瓦 - Varun Dhawan  218 人收藏 性别: 男 星座: 金牛座 出生日期: 1987-04-24 出生地: 印度,孟买 更多中文名: 瓦伦·达万

In Mandarin, your name presents several problems. First, except for a sort of imported pronunciation of some words in some regions, there is no “v” sound. I had a teacher from Zhejiang province who pronounced his “w” sounds as “v,” and starting your Chinese name with a “w” would probably be the way most people would transliterate your name. Your name ends with a final consonant, and Mandarin has only two of them. Fortunately, one of them is “n.” If your name rhymes with “moon,” then phonetically it would probably end up being translated as something that transliterates as “Wa-ru-en” and sounds more-or-less like “wah-roo-un.” “Watson” is transliterated as 沃森Wò sēn, so the first character of “Wa-ru-en” might be 沃. For the last character we could use the same one as in Zhou En-lai’s name, 恩 ēn. For “ru” 儒rú might work. 沃儒恩 Wò rú ēn would be a sort of mechanical transliteration of your name. A native speaker could probably come up with something much more fitting.

I like ur name Negar. Selvester Yang has got the good answer. Actually, different Chinese character names have totally different meanings [1]. The perfect name should have the special meanings. Hence, I highly recommend “纳吉” for two reasons: “吉” is very local Chinese name meaning “吉祥(Lucky)”“纳” means incorporating many thing with the generous characters. In further, u can expand the meaning according to ur career. For example, if u r writer (such as, poet) “纳” reminds us the popular guy “纳兰性德[2] ”. If u do finance, “纳斯达克(Nasdaq)” shows ur expert.It’s always fun to share the names meaning with ur friends.  Image is from online. It will be removed if Infringing ur rights. Ref [1] Why so many definitions associated with each word? [2] Nalan Xingde - Wikipedia

Chinese don't have all the alphabets(Characters) or pronounciation as in English, so non native people or foreigners Choose a new name. So many people choose random name or a word that have same meaning as your name. Many foreigner only choose first name and some people choose a full name. TOTALLY NEW NAME . I would say it's like a new life… you get to choose a new name without having any attachment to your original name. Even many Japanese, Koreans and other Asian people have another name in Chinese, even though they have similarities in language but still they select a new. I Hope you can select a beautiful name! Thank You!

贾诗琳 — JIA Shilin in Chinese style. 贾（JIA），usual Chinese surname；诗（Shi），poem；琳（Lin），beautiful jade。 I also want to add that a famous role in an old Chinese classical novel “Dream of the Red Chamber”《红楼梦》 named “贾宝玉” （JIA Baoyu）which “宝玉” means “invaluale jade”。Furthermore，he is also good at peoms in the story：） You see，Chinese nation is a jade nation

I don’t know if it is your family name for I didn’t get its Chinese name from dictionary. If you want to translate it directly, other answers may be more helpful.If you want to get a traditional Chinese name, I will tell you how to name yourself and your friends. Your name sounds like 艾伦 so we can choose 艾 as your Chinese family name.This word means sailor, right?(I’m not sure) We will search it in Chinese poems. I find these words: 1.知津 It’s from an old poem in Song dynasty which is called 水龙吟. 知 means you know something very well, 津 means waters like sea or river. So the word meas you know every water and you are erudite. 2.行舟 It’s from a famous Tang poem called 渡荆门送别 and its writer is Li Bai, who is one of the greatest poets that ever lived in China. The sentence is 仍怜故乡水，万里送行舟, Li Bai wrote it when he left his hometown to travel to another province. It means when you look at the water on the boat, it will remind your feelings of hometown. The river become alive and make a long-way farewell to you. You leave home but you will always miss it. Now you get two Chinese name to use, 艾知津 and 艾行舟, they are natural and sounds beautiful to our Chinese. Don’t forget me if you decide to use one of them.

Hi there! Your name would be pronounced “jia si lin” in Chinese, hereafter how my wife (who is Chinese) would write it: 贾思林 (female) 贾思琳 (male) I found a video on youtube about western names in Chinese, quite funny!  Have fun!
In Chinese, your name can be translated as "艾琳", which pronunciation is "ài lín".
Both simplified Chinese and traditional Chinese are 艾琳(ài lín).

Your name is quite relate to Chinese name, Kim is relate to Chinese surname 金, and Rie is relate to character 莉 and 俪，both are fomous in girls name, so, 金莉 and 金俪 are both good.

In Cantonese, if it's a girl, the name Erlyn is transliterated as 艾蓮，艾玲 or 艾琳。 If it's a boy, then it's 艾倫。
There is no way to convert an alphabetical name into Chinese way. You just have to put a letter pronounced similarly and combine them.
If you just want to translate your English name to Chinese according to similarity of sound. I recommend “艾琳”.
If you are a Japanese girl, I prefer to use “理惠” or “里惠”。
